question: Do teachers judge parents by the lunches they send their kids to school with?
answer: My son is allergic to milk (NOT lactose-intolerant) so he took his lunch every day. He often had things like burritos or tacos, made at home, and always fruit and a juice box or a bottle of water. One teacher complained that he never had cheese or yogurt like most kids and I had to tell her to check his file. Those things could kill him! She assured me that everybody needed some dairy every day and reminded me that lactose free foods were available. I told my son not to eat anything she wanted to add to his lunch and referred her to the school nurse who was familiar with his reaction to dairy. It was life-threatening! The nurse reported that the woman didn't believe her either. Fortunately, my son remembered well the time his father bought him a hot dog that had milk in the bun. He ate hot dogs at home (dairy-free) all the time and hubby just never thought to check. Fortunately they got to me pretty quickly, I had the epi-pen and inhaler, and he threw up most of it as well. He never wanted to feel that way again, in pain and struggling to breathe! He wouldn't eat anything not approved by Mom. Saved his life more than once, I am sure.

question: What, if any, changes did you notice after going dairy free?
answer: I noticed that my coffee didn’t taste nearly as good. There were reasonable substitutes for most recipes, but not for cheese. I happen to really love good cheese, so I started craving cheese. Whipped cream and frosting were also not nearly as good when made with dairy substitutes (it’s hard to get the texture without the frosting getting too sweet). But other than that, my life didn’t change much. No health benefits that I noticed. A few years later, we treated my son’s anaphylactic allergy to dairy, and I was able to re-introduce dairy to my diet again. Hooray! High-quality dairy products make a small but significant contribution to the quality of my life.

question: Why are avocados classified as not vegan?
answer: Almonds, cherries, plums, avocados, alfalfa, sunflowers, clover, squash, clementines, tangerines, cranberries, blueberries, pumpkins, apples, and a whole assortment of other vegetables could be on the non-vegan list. What do these crops have in common? They are all pollinated by Apis mellifera, the European Honeybee. Hives of bees are transported around the country in complicated rotation as the crops bloom, so they can visit the fields and pollinate the plants. Without the hardworking little bees, we would have far fewer fruits, nuts and vegetables to put on the vegan table. Vegans object to using honeybees to pollinate crops, especially almonds and avocados because those are the heaviest users of bees. It is thought that the stress of constant transportation contributes to colony collapse, an issue that has become increasingly problematic. Vegans object to the exploitation of honeybees, either by taking (they say stealing) their honey, or by transporting them around to fertilize crops. But keeping track of which crops are pollinated by migratory bees and which are not, and figuring out how crops that require honeybees to pollinate them can be grown without the industrious insects, makes the issue a little more complicated than simply avoiding almonds and avocados. Both are good sources of healthy fats, protein and other nutrients essential when you are eating a meat and dairy free diet. https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/migratory-beekeeping-mind-boggling-math/ Home sick: impacts of migratory beekeeping on honey bee (Apis mellifera) pests, pathogens, and colony size

question: What is the most disrespectful thing you ever saw or heard in a restaurant, coming from a tourist?
answer: Not sure if disrespectful or unobservant or even just plain dumb. There's a tiny little restaurant in the Latin Quarter in Paris called Le Chat Qui Peche (the Fishing Cat). The signage clearly says it specialises in regional specialities (mainly from near the Alps). The large and unmissable lettering in the windows boasts of raclettes, tartiflettes and fondue which featured strongly in the menu displayed outside. We are talking serious cheese consumption here with almost every dish containing vast amounts of delicious melted cheese. Even the onion soup is served with toasted bread and melted cheese, as is tradition. We stumbled across this restaurant one bitterly cold November day and nothing was more appealing than hot melted cheese with crusty bread, potatoes and ham. Just as we had been served our seriously cheesy main course and loosened our belts in preparation, two young American ladies entered and were seated. The whining started almost immediately. They both wanted dairy-free food and were harassing the very confused waiter as the only items on the menu they could possibly eat were sides of French fries or green salad. They eventually stomped out in disgust saying they would complain to every restaurant guide and the US Embassy. People, if you are on a restricted diet, please have the sense to have a quick look at the type of cuisine offered by a restaurant and a longer look at the menu.

question: The vegan lifestyle is incredibly expensive and harmful. Why are people still vegan?
answer: You are wrong on all counts. It is not expensive to be a vegan because plant-based foods cost a lot less than meat and dairy-based foods. Of course, for vegans to save that cash, they need to be ready to shop for produce and learn how to cook it. Even if you are the kind of vegan who is willing to spend money on vegan processed foods, like dairy-free cheese (disgusting) plant-based meat substitutes (so disappointing) and imported coconut and tamarind yogurt at $3.95 a tub, it still won’t cost as much as meat and real dairy. And a vegan diet is not harmful. The only essential nutrient missing from vegan and some vegetarian diets is B12, and you can take that as a supplement. Now, I have mentioned vegans I have known whose diet is based on canned creamed corn and Skittles, but I don’t think those people count as vegans. They just like to say they are vegans. Most of the vegans I know have a clue about how to feed themselves well without animal products because they know about a variety of vegetables, legumes and nuts, and they know how to cook. People become vegans for all kinds of reasons. Most are perfectly nice people who don’t feel the need to remind you constantly that meat is death. The worst thing about vegans is trying to find a restaurant you are all ok with eating at. If you get stuck with a dear friend sitting across the table from you who spends ten minutes interrogating the waitstaff about secret chicken broth and bootleg butter, you can become homicidal kinda fast, especially if you are hungry. This is the closest veganism comes to being dangerous: the hostility of family and friends. But expensive and harmful? I’m afraid you have been misinformed, my dear.

question: What should you say to your server if you want to send your food back?
answer: I have a son with a dairy allergy, so unfortunately this happens much more frequently than I care for. Just yesterday - at a higher-priced small chain restaurant with 3–5 locations - my son ordered off the vegan menu something like a chicken parmesan sandwich - breaded chicken breast, vegan mozzarella, and tomato sauce. [Edited here to add that the vegan menu offered vegan chicken or grilled tofu … my son checked the ingredients with the server for regular breaded chicken since he’s not technically vegan and that chicken was safe to eat.] The server took note of the order (“vegan cheese”), and went off. The sandwiches all finally arrive (there were four of us) and his has a sprinkle of what looks like parmesan cheese on the outside of the bread. Call the waitress back, point out what looks like regular cheese on the outside (assuming that the cheese inside the sandwich is dairy free, but who knows) and ask her to check with the kitchen. She comes back with a plate of fries, apologizing appropriately about the sandwich with a comment that it’ll be a few minutes while they make a new one. Looking at the plate of fries, there is melted cheese on the fries in the corner - I assume it’s from either his very own plate (and thus dairy free cheese) or a sloppy kitchen that spilled cheese of some sort into the fry tray. My son is allergic, this is not a food preference, so I call over the manager. He takes the fries back with another hearty apology. Very soon the server comes back with a complimentary cup of chili for my son - he had made a comment about chili earlier. This was a very good gesture of good will. By this point my husband was nearly through his sandwich, my sister was 80% done with her entree salad, and I had eaten only half of my fries but was waiting on my own sandwich out of solidarity with my son who had eaten very little so far while waiting. The sandwich is finally delivered by the manager. We smile and say it looks good, thanks for checking on it. My son immediately realizes that they gave him DOUBLE breaded chicken breast inside - probably to say “sorry”. He also notices cheddar cheese instead of mozzarella… on a chicken parmesan sandwich. Who uses cheddar on a chicken parm? Oh well… he didn’t want to wait another 10 minutes for them to correct it *again* to the original order.

question: What is an open secret in your profession that we regular folk don't know or generally aren't allowed to be told about?

question: What can an inexperienced cook make as an entree for large numbers of people?
answer:
Hi Scott, for an inexperienced cook, a large number of people could be 10–20. If you ask most housewife’s or their husbands, to prepare a dinner for 10 to 20 guests, they would have nightmares.
The same is true if you ask many professional chefs to prepare for an event of 100 or 200 guests. It’s only scary when you have never cooked or prepared for that number before. I recall being in a team here in London, where we cooked for 6000 for a Vodafone sponsored event, we had 11 separate kitchens, 10 kitchens providing for 600 covers each, 1 kitchen providing for all/any dietary differences, vegans, gluten-free, dairy free, Kosher etc. So “entree” Aka a starter, appetiser, Hors d’oeuvre, prepared by an inexperienced cook! It needs to be simple, simple with ingredients and execution. It needs to have the plating, practised many times before the event, get some Visual inspiration from books or the Internet.
Pick a theme or Culinary direction for the meal, and Follow-through.
I'd go with smoked salmon, it's simple, can be prepared ahead of time, the plate garnish can remain a wedge of lemon, some cucumber 🥒, and buttered brown bread, and smoked salmon. 20 covers will need 2kg sliced smoked salmon, 1 large cucumber, 4 lemons cut into 6 wedges, 1 loaf brown/granary bread, 200g soft butter, some extra fine capers, and a bunch of dill. 20 x 24cm or 10” white plates. I will include a plating idea too! Be safe out there. Im surprised that other answers have spaghetti, chilli, lasagne, baked potatoes Etc, as answers for ENTREE those are all “main course dishes” and not so simple to get right. I will add a few pictures of larger numbers I’ve cooked for to give an idea of scale.
